texts.shortText: Small to medium elongate shark with two small, triangular dorsal fins that lack anterior spines and are set far back, both behind pelvic fin, first dorsal fin slightly the larger. Tail with indistinct lower lobe. Pelvic fins completely fused to form a ‘pelvic curtain’. Colour light brown above with about 7–9 darker dorsal saddles, some with darker margins, and numerous white to light-yellow spots (no black spots). Underside cream.

Global: Endemic to Southern Africa.

Local/Regional: Namibia to KwaZulu-Natal, more common in the west. Record from India is an error.

A benthic species found mostly around deeper rocky reefs with literature records of 26–695 m depth. Fairly rarely photographed by divers although sometimes seen in shallow kelp forests. More common and occurs in shallower waters in the Western Cape; rarer and deeper in the warmer waters to the east. Curls up when disturbed.

Males mature at a length of about 84 cm and females at about 75 cm and males grow larger than females. Little else known about behaviour.
Feed on bony fish and various invertebrates, especially crustaceans and worms, also cephalopods.
Oviparous, females laying pairs of rectangular egg cases with long tendrils at each corner. Young are born at a length of about 25–27 cm.

Despite the name, spots can be white rather than yellow (at least in available live images, which may be of juveniles). Easily confused with Shysharks of the genus Haploblepharus, but these are smaller in size (<60 cm), occur in shallower waters and differ in details of colour pattern. Similar to the Puffadder shyshark H. edwardsii, but that species has much more pronounced tan saddles and more numerous, smaller white spots. The Dark shyshark H. pictus is much darker with almost black saddles and much less distinct spots.

Heemstra, P, Heemstra, E, Ebert, D, Holleman, W & Randall, J (2022). Coastal Fishes of the Western Indian Ocean. National Research Foundation & South African Institute for Aquatic Biodiversity, South Africa. Volume 1 (p. 492). 

Smith, MM & Heemstra, P (eds.) (2003). Smith's Sea Fishes. Struik Publishers, Cape Town (p. 95).
